Lipper is an alumna of the Hillary Clinton campaign and the Democratic National Committee. Lipper is a graduate of Indiana University.

@MiryamLipper: Senior Advisor for Communications & Strategy: Lipper previously served as Comms Director for Ossoff’s 2020 Senate campaign. Her high-level experience in strategic comms includes as a spokesperson for VP Harris during her presidential campaign & for Sen. Tim Kaine.
Parker has also worked as an area deputy to former Los Angeles Mayor Richard Riordan, field representative for California State Senator Herschel Rosenthal, and on statewide campaigns in California.

.@SteveParker_1: Deputy State Director: Parker previously served as Political Director for Sen. Ossoff’s 2020 Senate campaign, Senior City Attorney for the City of Atlanta, VP & Senior Counsel with Fidelity National Title Group, and  attorney with Balch & Bingham LLP.

Chandra Harris, State Director: Leading Sen. Ossoff’s State Office & overseeing constituent services, Harris previously served as District Director for GA Congressman David Scott. She rose from staff assistant to press secretary & went on to lead his GA office for over 10 years.

Turner previously worked for Georgia Senator Max Cleland, Georgia Congressman David Scott, and Senator Dick Durbin. Turner mostly recently served as a Senior Policy Advisor to the Senate Budget Committee under Chairman Bernie Sanders.

@DonniTurner1, Legislative Director: Leading Ossoff’s legislative team, Turner is a Georgia native with more than 20 years of public policy and Congressional experience. Turner is an alumna of Spelman College, Clark Atlanta University, and Howard University School of Law.

Rey Benitez, Chief of Staff: To lead Senator Ossoff’s team, Benitez brings a decade of experience advising Senate leadership. Benitez previously served as Chief of Staff to Senator Catherine Cortez Masto, and he was a Senior Advisor to former Senate Democratic Leader Harry Reid.

Transplants are the best option for people with kidney disease, but providers push them to stay on dialysis since they get a big pay day from insurers. I urged @HHS to investigate this, and I’m continuing to push for robust oversight.

https://twitter.com/RepKatiePorter/status/1153797061902422016 QT @RepKatiePorter I promised OC families that I'd fight to drive down healthcare costs and improve the quality of care. Today I called on @HHSGov to investigate corrupt practices in the dialysis industry that are putting patients’ lives at risk and making care more expensive.

The American Kidney Fund—an organization backed by top dialysis providers—often steers patients away from Medicare and towards more expensive insurance.

Why? Providers can easily jack up dialysis prices for commercial insurers, but not for Medicare.

https://healthpolicy.usc.edu/article/dialysis-costs-the-healthcare-system-3x-more-in-the-individual-market/

The law forbids discrimination against patients with disabilities, but insurers often exploit loopholes to deny coverage when it’s beneficial to their bottom line. I’m leading my House and Senate colleagues in asking the Administration to crack down on this immediately. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyOt1CpVoAc_Vb9.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyOt1NbVgAE3QYk.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyOt1kIU4AASNS5.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyOt15wVcAI4uwh.png

In the wake of Mike’s passing, my thoughts are with his family, whom he loved unconditionally. His three daughters will grow up with an example of what it truly means to demonstrate strength — and what it means to never give up the fight.

The Michael Lecik Military Firefighters Protection Act, which Mike and I worked on together, would change that — moving us closer to securing the benefits these heroes have earned.

Thank you @RepDonBacon for helping push this bipartisan effort forward.
https://spanberger.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=3696

While military firefighters are exposed to unique dangers through their work that lead many to develop service-related illnesses, the VA doesn’t recognize the direct connection between military firefighting and certain diseases, like cancer, beyond one year following active duty.

Following his service-related cancer diagnosis and VA-denied coverage, Mike Lecik fought to ensure that thousands of military firefighters received the proper care they earned in service to our country.

Today, it's my privilege to reintroduce a bill to fix this — in Mike's name. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EyPYrecWgAIVJR8.jpg

Why doesn’t the IRS go after wealthy Americans cheating on their taxes instead?

Put simply, it’s much cheaper to go after millions of poor Americans, who can’t afford the lawyers & loopholes that take up valuable processing time, than it is to go after multi-millionaires.

In Humphreys County, MS the median income is $26k, one of the poorest in the country.

Yet, residents there are audited at a rate 51% higher than they are in my district in Santa Clara County, where the median income is $126k.

Enough bailouts.

This funding could help health departments develop:
✅capabilities in testing & contact tracing,
✅guidance for schools, businesses, & communities,
✅effective, culturally competent ed. campaigns,
✅community partnerships,
✅better data collection,

PHISLA would do this by increasing funding for public health infrastructure over the next five years up to $4.5 billion in funding annually.

PHISLA would prevent us from ever being in this situation again. It provides billions in dedicated annual funding for federal, state, local, and Tribal public health departments to bolster our preparedness and response measures at all levels of government, for years to come.

The cost of leaving our communities unprepared for this pandemic has been devastating. Testing was slow to stand up, misinformation has been rampant, data remains incomplete, and inequities have been magnified.

We must learn from this crisis.
